trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised controlled trial of forearm strengthening exercises in osteoarthritis of the small joints of the hand
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In adults with primary osteoarthritis of the small joints of the hand, is a 12 week program of forearm strengthening exercises more effective than no exercises for improving pain and function?

conditions.healthcondition: Primary osteoarthritis of small joints of the hand

interventions.interventions: 12 weeks of forearm strengthening exercises, to be done at home by participants, consisting of a series of seven brief exercises performed ten times daily. Each set of exercises should take 3-5 minutes to complete. Full explanation of exercises will be given. Continue usual pain medications.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain in hands using a patient pain visual analogue scale, patient global visual analogue scale and physician global visual analogue scale.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Function in hands using cochin hand functional disability scale

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Painful osteoarthritis of small joints of the hand Pain visual analogue score >4 Stable analgesic dose in 4 weeks prior to inclusion Age > 18 years old Ability to give informed consent and comply with exercises
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Corticosteroids within last 3 months Diagnosis of inflammatory joint condition Unable to give informed consent

trial_design.concealment: Allocation concealment via sealed opaque envelopes
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by computer software (ie. computerised sequence generation).

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To determine the effictiveness of forearm strengthening exercises in controlling pain and improving function in painful osteoarthritis of the small joints of the hand
